news.title: 'Obnoxious': Kamala Harris Brutally Ridiculed for Giving Dating Advice — Despite Husband Doug Emhoff Famously Cheating on His First Wife With Children's Teacher
news.text:
Kamala Harris has been brutally ridiculed after doling out dating advice despite her husband, Doug Emhoff, cheating on his first wife with his kids' teacher, RadarOnline.com can reveal. 

The former presidential candidate revealed her tips on relationships while appearing on Tuesday's episode of the Rich Little Brokegirls podcast.What Advice Did Kamala Harris Give?Harris specifically spoke to "anyone who is single who wants to be in a relationship."

She advised them to "be kind to yourself and choose to be with someone who is kind."

"There are different phases in life, and depending on what phase you're in, maybe you're gonna choose that you want to have that kind of Friday night relationship or you want that Sunday morning relationship," she said while chuckling. "Sometimes you can get both, and sometimes they just is oil and water. And... that's okay. Be in those phases where you are having fun."Kamala Harris Slammed as a 'Fool' for Dating AdvicePeople immediately took to X to slam Harris for her advice, with one person writing, "Did her advice include not dating married men? My advice is don't take advice from Kamala Harris for anything...."

"Why the f--- would anyone take dating advice from Kamala Harris?" another person piped in to add.

"If she were honest, she'd say 'find a powerful, much older guy to give you a job and promote your career ahead of far better and more qualified people so you can fail your way to the top – when it's time to cash out, find a rich guy who b---- babysitters," another person noted. Emhoff had previously admitted to having an affair while with his first wife.

Still, others called Harris "obnoxious" and a "fool."Kamala Harris' 'Complicated' Relationship With Joe BidenAs far as Harris goes, people claiming she dated "married men" were referring to rumors of an affair with former San Francisco mayor Willie Brown. 

Aside from handing out dating tips, Harris got candid earlier this year about her "complicated" relationship with Joe Biden, whom she was the vice president under. 

When appearing on The Diary of a CEO podcast, Harris was asked if she thought Biden wanted her to win the 2024 election.

"I do...," she said after pondering the question. "Because I was the only one who would be able to preserve his legacy. But even that's about him."

"Well, if I had to assume one of the reasons why he'd want me to win...Yeah," she added.What Is Kamala Harris' Political Future?While she insisted she has "a great deal of affection for" Biden, she admitted she was "greatly disappointed" and "angered" by Biden in the past, especially when she stepped in as the Democratic nominee after he decided not to run for reelection.

While Harris was ultimately defeated by Donald Trump, she tiptoed around answering whether she would make another go at becoming president in 2028.

"I am not done. I have lived my entire career as a life of service, and it's in my bones," she said in an interview. 

She later noted her grandnieces would "see a female president in the White House in their lifetime, for sure" and admitted there's a possibility it could be her.
news.summary: Kamala Harris was ridiculed and slammed as 'obnoxious' for giving dating advice during a recent podcast appearance.
news.author: Matt Richards

news.title: Kamala Harris Gives Saucy Dating Advice, And It Might Make You Blush
news.text:
Now that’s the way to win a swing state.

Former Vice President Kamala Harris advised young singles campaigning for love to enjoy that “Friday night relationship” if they’re not ready for the “Sunday morning relationship.” (Watch the video below.)

On the “Rich Little Brokegirls” podcast posted Tuesday, the 2024 Democratic presidential nominee at first offered basic tips like, be kind to yourself and choose someone kind, “who allows you to laugh at yourself and them.”

Then she ventured into more intimate territory.

“There are different phases in your life,” she told host Kimberly Bizu. “And depending on what phase you’re in, maybe you’re going to choose that you want to have that kind of Friday night relationship or you want that Sunday morning relationship.” Harris laughed at her get-real guidance.

“Sometimes they go together and sometimes ...” Bizu chimed in.

“And sometimes you can get both, and sometimes it’s oil and water,” Harris continued. “And that’s OK. Be in those phases where you are having fun. Be in those phases where you have a sense of, you know, I just want something more.

“But be honest with yourself about what you’re in, and figure out whether what you’re in is actually what you want. Right? But the first step is to be honest about what you’re in. And not try and make it something that it’s not because that usually doesn’t work out so well.”

Harris met her husband, Doug Emhoff, on a blind date, and the pair wed in 2014.

Fast-forward to 14:20 to watch the exchange
news.author: Ron Dicker

news.title: List of Democrats' Double-Digit Overperformances in 2025 Elections
news.text: Democrats overperformed former Vice President Kamala Harris by double digits in special elections across the country in 2025. Democratic National Committee Deputy Executive Director Libby Schneider told Newsweek that the party should “feel buoyed by the strong results we’ve seen up and down the ballot all year long.” Why It Matters Off-year special elections can be a gauge of the mood of the electorate between the presidential election and midterms set for next November, when Democrats are hoping to reclaim control of the House and Senate. The results suggest heightened Democratic enthusiasm, and polls for next year give the party an edge. They also served as a test of President Donald Trump’s popularity, as he supported Republican candidates in many of these races. What To Know Democrats began 2025 in a tough spot, still grappling with former Vice President Kamala Harris’ loss in the last year’s presidential race. The party was divided about the best path forward as well as what contributed to Trump’s victory. Despite those woes, special elections this year yielded strong results for Democrats. House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries speaks during a news conference in Washington on May 5, 2025. Florida House Special Elections Democrats overperformed Harris’ margin by double digits in two Florida House special elections this year. Although Republicans still won each race, Democrats put up stronger-than-expected showings. In Florida’s 1st Congressional District, Republican Jimmy Patronis defeated Democrat Gay Valimont by about 14.6 percentage points, much narrower than Trump’s 37-point victory last November. In Florida’s 6th Congressional District, Republican Randy Fine defeated Democrat Josh Weil by about 14 points—a notable change from Trump’s 30-point victory in 2024. This race was viewed as being potentially competitive and drew national attention—and spending. Virginia’s 11th Congressional District Democrat James Walkinshaw overperformed in the special election to fill the seat vacated by the late Representative Gerry Connolly. He won the race in the Northern Virginia district by more than 50 points against Republican Stewart Whitson. Harris won the seat by 34 points last November. Arizona’s 7th Congressional District In Arizona’s 7th Congressional District, a seat that drifted rightward last November as Trump made inroads with Hispanic voters, Democrat Adelita Grijalva easily won the race to replace her father, the late Representative Raul Grijalva. She won her race by nearly 40 points, compared to Harris’ 22-point victory last November. Tennessee’s 7th Congressional District The special election in Tennessee’s 7th Congressional District to replace former Representative Mark Green, who left Congress for a private-sector job, was viewed as a competitive race by both parties. Democrats were hopeful that Aftyn Behn could defeat Republican Matt Van Epps, and the race drew investment from both parties. Van Epps, who received the support of Trump, ended up winning, but Behn still made the race closer than expected. He won by just under nine points, compared to Trump’s 22-point victory last year. Miami Mayoral Race Democrat Eileen Higgins this month defeated Republican Emilio Gonzalez by nearly 20 points in the Miami mayoral election. She secured just over 59 percent of the vote, while Gonzalez received just under 41 percent. That’s a strong improvement for Democrats from 2024, when Harris won Miami by less than a percentage point. Miami was once a Democratic stronghold but has shifted right as Republicans have made gains among Hispanic voters, especially Cuban voters who are prominent in Miami. Wisconsin Supreme Court Election Although Wisconsin’s Supreme Court elections are technically nonpartisan, liberal-aligned Susan Crawford won by double digits against the conservative-aligned Brad Schimel in a state that Democrats lost at the presidential level last November. Crawford won by just about 10 percentage points; Trump carried Wisconsin by less than a percentage point in last year’s election. State Legislative Elections Democrats outperformed Harris in the following state legislative races by double digits, according to The Downballot: What People Are Saying Democratic National Committee Deputy Executive Director Libby Schneider, in a statement to Newsweek: “With another 40%+ overperformance by a Democrat from the top of the 2024 ticket last week in Kentucky, and as Democrats enter the midterm year, our party should feel buoyed by the strong results we’ve seen up and down the ballot all year long. Across red, purple, and blue states, Democrats have gotten off the mat and proven that when you organize everywhere, you can win anywhere — in every part of the country.“ CNN data analyst Harry Enten, this month after the Miami mayoral race: “It is just the latest shift that we’re seeing. That is what I think is so important going on here. We’ve seen in special elections. We saw it in Virginia gov. We saw it in New Jersey gov. We’ve seen it across the political map, where over and over and over again, the baseline from 2024, Democrats are consistently outperforming it.” Red Eagle Politics, a conservative political commentary account with more than 110,000 followers on X: “Democrats do better in off-year elections now. Cool, we get it. The thing is, Dems were massively overperforming in countless specials every year since Obama left office, almost ALL went back to baseline in the Midterm or Presidential year.” What Happens Next Whether or not these special-election overperformances translate to a strong midterm showing will be seen next November. Polls are giving Democrats an advantage on the generic ballot, but the results of the midterms could be shaped by factors such as how the economy fares over the coming months.
news.summary: Democrats outperformed former Vice President Kamala Harris' margins in special elections across the country this year.
news.author: Andrew Stanton

news.title: ‘This woman ran for President’: Kamala Harris’s dating advice sparks debate online
news.text: For the time being as she takes a sabbatical from politics, Democrat leader Kamala Harris seems to be making a career move towards a dating coach. The former Vice President has been making quite the headlines on the dating advice she has for young girls and rather than making it easier for them, it seems she has them confused. On Tuesday, Harris appeared on the “Rich Little Broke Girls” podcast and shared amusing dating advice with her signature cackle. According to her, you can have all you want whenever you want. Kamala Harris’s dating adviceHarris, 61, who married Douglas Emhoff in 2014 had something really interesting to say to all the young and single woman dating out there. “Choose to be with someone who allows you to laugh at yourself and them,” said Harris. “Choose to be with someone who you know you like, going to the grocery store together, taking a walk together.”Up till here, her advice seemed like one from a wise woman who has experienced both dating and marriage. But soon, the tables turned. Harris also stated that there are “different phases in your life and you may not know what phase you’re in.”“Maybe you’re going to choose that you want to have that kind of Friday night relationship — or you want that Sunday morning relationship,” she continued. “Sometimes you can get both — and sometimes they just is oil and water. And that’s OK! Be in those phases where you are having fun!” she added. “Enjoy dating, by the way, because dating is fun. It’s supposed to be. Just do what, at the end of the day, when you go to sleep at night and when you wake up in the morning, makes you feel like, ‘I’m good,’” she suggested.While she met and married her husband in their 40s, she added that she couldn’t tell if they “would have really been in the same place” if they had met in their 20s.Netizens react to Kamala Harris’ dating advicePeople on the internet are less than impressed with Harris’s dating advice. As a former Vice President and presidential candidate, it seems the expectations for her were high. Americans wanted a wise and profound advice from her, but what they got was a casual dating tip. And it has left them enraged, considering it is coming from an experienced politician.“Nothing profound, but she acts like it's deep wisdom. Hard to believe this woman ran for president. But hey, Dems—please nominate her again in 2028. I’m begging you,” said a post on X. “Sounds like a cyclical recipe for insecurity and constant self-questioning of one's worth, based on sexuality's power dynamics. Figuring this out on your own is one thing; having a political leader say it is another,” pointed out another. “Was this career advancement or relationship advice? Can never tell with that one...,” trolled another referring to Harris’ past relationship with Willie Brown. “Honestly, the advice itself isn’t that crazy. She’s basically saying different people serve different roles in different seasons of life, and that it’s okay to be honest about what you want at the time. Some people will hear this as empowering, others will see it as unserious coming from a politician,” explained an X user. Kamala Harris on being a ‘humble’ womanElsewhere in the interview, Harris recalled a reporter asking her about criticisms of her lack of humility. "I don’t aspire to be humble. Humility, yes, is very important. [It’s] a very dated perspective on who women should be. To say that women should be humble. Women should be quiet. Women should laugh quietly," she said."Women should not have a sense of humour. Women should not raise their voice," she continued. "I have never felt burdened by those very dated, and I think out-of-touch standards." In an April 2024 interview with Drew Barrymore, she also addressed the criticism she faced on her signature cackle. "Well, let me just tell you something: I have my mother’s laugh," she continued. "And I grew up around a bunch of women, in particular, who laughed from the belly."While the netizens are expecting something sage from the politician all the time, sometimes one can be just an honest woman and share a tip that is ideal for a modern woman. Not everything around a politician needs to be politicised. Additionally, there were others on the internet who also found her dating advice ideal, writing comments such as, “Dating advice from Kamala Harris is something I never knew I needed but love to have.”
news.author: Toi World Desk

news.title: Harris Suggests Mocking Her Laugh Is Sexist, As She Gives Young Women Dating Advice
news.text:
Kamala Harris suggested that those who make fun of her cackle are simply sexist, on an episode of the “Rich Little Broke Girls” podcast, where the former vice president and failed 2024 Democratic presidential candidate was providing the show's listeners with dating advice.

“I don’t aspire to be humble. Humility, yes, is very important,” Harris said when asked about the criticism that she lacks humility. “[It’s] a very dated perspective on who women should be. To say women should be humble, women should be quiet, women should laugh quietly.”

“Women should not have a sense of humor. Women should not raise their voice,” she went on. “I have never felt burdened by those very dated, and I think out-of-touch standards.”

Surprisingly, Harris largely avoided identity politics during her short presidential run. 

After losing to President Trump, she wrote a book titled 107 Days detailing her campaign and embarked on a promotional tour. In the book, she blamed everyone from the American people to her former boss, Joe Biden, for her loss, throwing several high-profile Democrats under the bus. Yet publicly, she has been unwilling to voice those same criticisms.

“Choose to be with someone who allows you to laugh at yourself and them,” she said. “Choose to be with someone who you know you like, going to the grocery store together, taking a walk together.”

“There are different phases in your life, and you may not know what phase you’re in,” Harris explained. “Maybe you’re going to choose that you want to have that kind of Friday night relationship, or you want that Sunday morning relationship."

“Maybe you’re going to choose that you want to have that kind of Friday night relationship, or you want that Sunday morning relationship.

“Sometimes you can get both — and sometimes they just is oil and water. And that’s OK! Be in those phases where you are having fun!”

“Doug and I got married in our 40s, and I love my husband so very much. He is my best friend,” she reflected.

“And we’ve talked about it, if we had met in our 20s, I don’t know that we would have really been in the same place.”

Harris should also be among the last people offering dating advice to young women, given that she famously launched her political career while dating former San Francisco mayor and political kingmaker Willie Brown. Harris’s introduction to the broader political stage largely occurred during their year-and-a-half relationship. 

While serving as Speaker of the California State Assembly, Brown appointed Harris to the California Unemployment Insurance Appeals Board and later placed her on the California Medical Assistance Commission, two positions that gave her significant political visibility. He also introduced her to the state’s political elite and Democratic donor network, paving the way for her eventual run for California attorney general.

news.title: Bari Should Fire Them!
news.text:
The Left plays by different rules, and while I disagree with people who argue that we should adopt the same rules to fight them, that doesn't mean that we should pretend that people who are not good-faith actors should be treated the same as those who are. 

As Ed has written about in two posts, the controversy over Bari Weiss's delay of a 60 Minutes story on Trump's deportation of illegal aliens to El Salvador's CECOT has completely gotten out of hand. 

Not only was Weiss right about the story not being balanced, but now we know that the "journalists" who put together the story and leaked it to Canadian media actually lied to her and the world about the reporting that they did. 

Elon is absolutely right. There is no point tinkering at the margins by debating wording, editing choices, or how a segment might be polished or improved. The problem is not execution. The entire 60 Minutes operation is corrupted, and it has been for a very long time, going back… https://t.co/jApBVI80Mk— Hans Mahncke (@HansMahncke) December 24, 2025

Elon is absolutely right. There is no point tinkering at the margins by debating wording, editing choices, or how a segment might be polished or improved. The problem is not execution. The entire 60 Minutes operation is corrupted, and it has been for a very long time, going back at least to the Dan Rather fake letter episode, which was explicitly designed to take down George W. Bush.That was followed by a long series of scandals, including 60 Minutes loudly insisting that Biden family corruption claims had been debunked, insisting that Hunter Biden’s laptop was not verified, and, more recently, deceptively stitching together Kamala Harris’s incoherent word salad into something that resembled a coherent answer. These are not the mistakes of a newsroom that occasionally gets something wrong. They are the consistent behaviors of a political propaganda operation.Framing this as a debate about journalistic standards completely misses the point. These are political operatives, not reporters, and the only serious course of action is to shut the operation down and rebuild from scratch with entirely new people.

Everybody is pretending that this controversy is about journalistic standards and whether 60 Minutes did its work appropriately. There is a lot of talk about Standards and Practices, lawyers, vetting, and the like, as if crossing all the Ts and dotting all the Is in a manner that might keep CBS on just the right side of the "slander" line were the point. 

Some nuggets in here @axios:- Can confirm WH, State Dept and DHS all provided on record comment in response to CBS News journalists’ request for comment ahead of the segment. None of those comments made airhttps://t.co/hFkRmt5Uv9— Sara Fischer (@sarafischer) December 22, 2025

That's not even close to the point, and neither is the claim that every statement in the story is factual (which turns out not to be the case, if that matters by now). 

I can make factual statements about somebody that, for instance, pass the "factual" test without actually conveying truth. For instance, I could say that Dan Rather fondled his mother's breasts regularly, and that would be factually correct, and without context would be a shocking assertion. If I added that he was an infant breastfeeding at the time, the truth of the matter would be revealed by the context. The first statement makes him sound like a pervert; the second makes him sound perfectly normal. 

Sharyn Alfonsi’s producer for the botched DeSantis story (Oriana Zill de Granados) is also the producer for the CECOT story. https://t.co/BByr8wnMan— Chuck Ross (@ChuckRossDC) December 23, 2025

If a "journalist" only reports the "fact" without proper context, it's clear that they are not using "journalistic" judgment to inform people of important information; they intend to slander somebody in the slyest way possible and get away with it. 

That is the sort of thing that went on here, just as has gone on at 60 Minutes for years. By massaging words or facts in ways intended to manipulate the viewer, these "reporters" are acting as political propagandists, not journalists getting to the truth. 

They are doing the same thing to discredit Bari Weiss, accusing her of giving Donald Trump a "kill switch" on their reporting. 

Those of us who are interested in the truth—and I don't mean by that "conservatives," but rather all people who are interested in understanding reality and communicating its nature fairly and accurately—need to get past the idea that we must pretend that Pravda propaganda is just another type of journalism. 

“Our story was screened five times and cleared by both CBS attorneys and Standards and Practices,” Ms. Alfonsi wrote in the note, a copy of which was obtained by The New York Times. “It is factually correct. In my view, pulling it now, after every rigorous internal check has been met, is not an editorial decision, it is a political one.”Ms. Weiss said in a statement late Sunday: “My job is to make sure that all stories we publish are the best they can be. Holding stories that aren’t ready for whatever reason — that they lack sufficient context, say, or that they are missing critical voices — happens every day in every newsroom. I look forward to airing this important piece when it’s ready.”

Propagandists aren't journalists, and we should quit acting as if they can be negotiated with or persuaded. As you can see from the very fact that the "journalists" in question lied about whether the administration would comment on their story, and then leaked their drivel into the media after their Editor in Chief told them to do better, these people have an agenda. They want to "get" Trump and they want to evict Bari Weiss. 

They should be fired, not coddled or negotiated with.
news.author: David Strom
